author: Adam Blevins
title: 'Kraven the Hunter' Fails To Hunt Down One Final Worldwide Box Office Milestone
text:
There were plenty of box office flops in 2024, and while some were easier to predict than others, perhaps the one that everyone saw coming was Kraven the Hunter. The film came at a time when the world was seemingly at the end of its rope with the SSU (Sony's Spider-Man Universe), which features movies centered on Spider-Man villains but no Spider-Man. Kraven was the most expensive Sony Marvel movie yet, boasting a budget of around $110 million, but the film is poised to finish its theatrical run as the lowest-grossing movie in the franchise by a long shot. At the time of writing, Kraven the Hunter has grossed $24.8 million domestically and $34.9 million internationally, bringing its worldwide total to $59 million globally, and it does not look like it will reach the $60 million threshold.
Kraven the Hunter will become the only Sony Marvel movie to finish with less than $100 million at the box office, as even Madame Web was able to narrowly scrape by and get its earnings into the nine-figures. However, while most people view the SSU as a colossal financial failure, the franchise has actually fared better than you might expect. Thanks to the success of the Venom movies, which have collectively grossed over $1.8 billion from three films at the worldwide box office, Sony has been able to recuperate its losses from other movies such as Morbius, Madame Web, and now Kraven. Each Venom movie needed around $200 million to break even with the rest being pure profit, so the symbiote franchise collectively earned the studio more than $1 billion to pad its pockets.
Who Stars in ‚ÄòKraven the Hunter‚Äô?
Aaron Taylor-Johnson features in the lead role of Kraven the Hunter, and even his undeniable charm wasn't enough to win over audiences or critics. Ariana DeBose also features alongside Taylor-Johnson as Calypso Ezili, with Gladiator 2 star Fred Hechinger portraying Dmitri Kravinoff. The Brutalist star Alessandro Nivola also features in Kraven the Hunter alongside Christopher Abbott and Russell Crowe. It almost makes it both more sad and impressive that Kraven the Hunter was able to fail so spectacularly at the box office, considering it has arguably a stronger cast than any other Sony Marvel movie.
Kraven the Hunter is still playing in extremely limited theaters, but the film is also available to watch at home on digital platforms. Stay tuned to Collider for more updates and watch Kraven the Hunter on Prime Video.

author: John Moody
title: Graduating Redbirds: Music education major, a first-generation college graduate, is ready to inspire her students
text:
Valeska Carrillo takes special pride in being the first in her family to earn a college degree. Raised in Aurora by parents who came to the U.S. from Mexico, she always dreamed of going to college.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve been looking forward to my graduation ever since I was a little girl,‚Äù Carrillo said. ‚ÄúMy parents have always been humble, hardworking people, and I am fortunate that they always understood the value of education and encouraged me to pursue higher education.
‚ÄúI remember my dad doing my hair before school and telling me how vital a college education is.‚Äù
Her parents, Alma Delia and Jose Guadalupe, will be there to share in her graduation moment. Imani Saucedo, her close friend, co-worker, and roommate‚Äîwho will be accompanied by her dog QP‚Äîwill also be there. Saucedo is graduating that day too.
A music education major with a minor in Spanish, Carrillo, 23, hopes to make an impact on her future students similar to the one her professors made on her at Illinois State University. With trombone as her main instrument, one of her most influential teachers was Dr. Mark Babbitt who helped build her musicianship skills in his role as her applied professor.
‚ÄúOut of all the lessons I had with different professors at different institutions, Dr. Babbitt stuck out most to me,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúOddly enough, he had the most criticism of my playing. I felt like many professors tried to sugarcoat feedback just to recruit me. But Dr. Babbitt got straight to the point, gave me practice tips, warm-up packets, and repertoire suggestions, which I really valued.‚Äù
Babbitt pushed her to do her best and believed in her when her self-confidence was low.
‚ÄúIf it wasn‚Äôt for him, I don‚Äôt know if I would have survived college,‚Äù Carrillo said. ‚ÄúHe is one of my role models.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôve been looking forward to my graduation ever since I was a little girl. My parents have always been humble, hardworking people, and I am fortunate that they always understood the value of education.‚Äù
Valeska Carrillo Proud of her heritage, she grew up speaking Spanish at home, eating delicious pan dulce, and listening to cumbia and m√∫sica norte√±a. For her recital, she chose music written by Mexican composers. Babbitt had encouraged her to seek just such a diverse repertoire.
‚ÄúAt my recital, I made sure to not only include the program notes about each piece, but to introduce them in Spanish,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt was important to me to provide a sense of authenticity. It was a project that required countless hours of research and ultimately took me a year to complete.
‚ÄúDr. Babbitt enjoyed one of the pieces so much, Soliloquio de un Andariego by Odin Zamorano Reyes, that he performed it for his own faculty recital in October of 2023.‚Äù
Carrillo decided on Illinois State after being selected as a high school student to participate in the Illinois Music Education Association (ILMEA) Band Festival. Some of the state‚Äôs most talented musicians were chosen to prepare a selection of concert band pieces. It was during the fall of 2018, and the guest conductor was Dr. Anthony Marinello, Illinois State‚Äôs director of bands. He made a lasting impression.
‚ÄúI, and everyone else there, was captivated by his lively personality,‚Äù Carrillo said. ‚ÄúI remember we were astounded with his high singing range. He said, ‚ÄòI used to sing with my mother in church.‚Äô
‚ÄúI chatted with him after the performance about my interest in pursuing music, and he encouraged me to audition for ISU‚Äôs School of Music,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat was a memorable moment for me, and Dr. Marinello never seemed to forget either. Whenever I would bump into him on the Quad, he always stopped to say hello.‚Äù
In addition, she appreciated the dedication of Dr. Shawn McNamara.
‚ÄúShout out to Dr. McNamara for being an incredibly insightful, understanding, and admirable professor,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe would go out of his way to help any student and even wrote me a few letters of recommendation. I will miss his general music class where we sang nursery rhymes and played different Orff instruments.‚Äù
Part of Carrillo‚Äôs decision to come to Illinois State was due to the tuition waiver that incoming music majors are considered for, based on their audition performances.
‚ÄúI must have nailed that audition because I was fortunate enough to receive a huge tuition waiver. It covered nearly half of my tuition,‚Äù she said.
Over the years, she also received the Patrick Sarsfield Gilmore Band Award, the Charles Stokes Music Scholarship, and the Resident Assistant Academic Scholarship.
Apply to Illinois State University Inspired by her parents‚Äô work ethic, Carrillo held a number of jobs to help get her through college. She was a resident assistant in Watterson; then a service area manager at Watterson, working the front desk and mailroom; and she was a service area student supervisor. She was also a Preview guide, and back home, she worked seasonal jobs at the mall.
Jacob Pourchot, a service area coordinator with University Housing Services, worked with Carrillo beginning in the fall of 2020 and was her direct supervisor for a time.
‚ÄúValeska flourished as a leader,‚Äù Pourchot said. ‚ÄúShe was a vital part of my team, and I do not know what I would have done without her. She was never afraid to put in the extra work, and she was the voice of the student workers at Watterson Towers. Her determination, heart, and focus made her so invaluable in the workplace. I am excited to see all that she will do in her career as an educator.‚Äù
Carrillo said she‚Äôll miss the beauty of campus, its plant life, squirrels, and bunnies. And she‚Äôll miss skating late at night with her friends on the Quad. But she‚Äôs ready to get started and is looking forward to being in a classroom.
‚ÄúI‚Äôll be substitute teaching in the spring of 2025 while looking for a full-time position as a band director in the suburbs,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd also like to be involved with ILMEA‚Äînow as a music educator‚Äîand continue to inspire students like me.‚Äù
This story is one of a series of profiles featuring Redbirds who are graduating this December . For more information about how Illinois State is celebrating commencement, visit the Graduation Services website .

author: Kristen Linthicum
title: CCSD graduates find a home in UGA‚Äôs Foundation Fellowship
text: For young people growing up in Athens, the University of Georgia provides greenspace to play, spots for annual field trips, and opportunities for internships, among other activities. But, for a group of Clarke County School District alumni, the University of Georgia also has become a launching pad to new discoveries, global travel and meaningful relationships. Through UGA‚Äôs Foundation Fellowship, five CCSD graduates are currently attending the university on a full academic scholarship as well as funding for travel-study, research and conferences. The fellowship is the university‚Äôs most prestigious academic program and creates a community for top scholars at UGA. ‚ÄúI owe so much of the joy and success of the college experience to the Foundation Fellowship,‚Äù said Dani Garcia-Pozo, a fourth-year student who graduated from Clarke Central High School. ‚ÄúIt has introduced me to a community of fantastic, deeply kind people who really want to see you succeed. I‚Äôve met one of my best friends through the program who encouraged me to travel abroad.‚Äù The fellowship supported Garcia-Pozo‚Äôs travel abroad to places like the United Kingdom, Ecuador, Spain and Cuba. His travels helped him become fluent in Spanish. These Clarke County graduates have found a strong sense of community and support through the Foundation Fellowship. ‚ÄúI always thought I wanted to get out of Athens, but after interning with the Young Dawgs program, I realized UGA was perfect for me,‚Äù said Patrick Allen, a first-year student who graduated from Clarke Central High School. ‚ÄúYoung Dawgs showed me great professors and a depth of resources, and then the Foundation Fellowship was almost like a family.‚Äù The Clarke County graduates have remained connected to their hometown, volunteering at nonprofits and showcasing local restaurants and businesses to fellow UGA students. ‚ÄúComing from Athens I‚Äôm more aware of the challenges facing Clarke County, and I‚Äôm always looking for more opportunities to serve,‚Äù said Ella Johnson, a second-year student who graduated from Cedar Shoals High School. ‚ÄúI joined First-Year Forum my freshman year and worked with Campus Kitchen for a year. This year, I‚Äôm focusing on literacy, which was an issue I saw in my [K-12] schools.‚Äù This year, Johnson will participate in the Books for Keeps Storytellers Literacy Mentor Program. As a volunteer, Johnson will meet with two students at Fowler Drive Elementary School once a week to help with their literacy and early reading skills. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve also tried to get my friends to get out in Athens-Clarke County to volunteer, because many students don‚Äôt realize the need that exists,‚Äù Johnson said. In addition to her community service as a UGA AmeriCorps Community Food Fellow, third-year student and Cedar Shoals High School graduate Hadiza Sarr began a project to help connect UGA students to local businesses. ‚ÄúAs an Athens native, I‚Äôm always being asked for recommendations of where to eat or shop,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI thought I‚Äôd centralize the information and help nascent businesses get discovered by UGA students.‚Äù In addition to the Foundation Fellows, students from across Athens have found a home at UGA. Currently, more than 120 students who graduated from CCSD high schools attend the University of Georgia. ‚ÄúUGA Admissions works hard and has had tremendous success in keeping our wonderful Athens-Clarke County students at UGA for their college years, as we have seen them go on to do great things both at Georgia and in their post graduate experiences,‚Äù said David Graves, UGA‚Äôs director of admissions. Many of these students ‚Äî and their peers from other communities ‚Äî remain in Athens, starting businesses, raising families and contributing to the community. Nearly 31,000 Athens residents are UGA alumni.

author: Akash Pandey
title: Watch: Google AI teaches robot to tie shoelaces
text: Google's DeepMind has successfully trained a robot to tie shoelaces, hang a shirt, and even fix fellow robots, marking a significant milestone in the field of artificial intelligence (AI). The company shared this achievement via a tweet on X. However, it was noted that the robot's shoelace-tying skills are still in their early stages and need improvement. Despite this, the development represents an important step toward enabling robots to perform complex tasks independently. The robot developed by DeepMind uses a technique known as bi-arm manipulation to tie shoelaces. This method involves the use of both arms, a feature that sets it apart from other robots. The robot is powered by two new AI systems: ALOHA Unleashed and DemoStart. ALOHA Unleashed assists the robot in performing complex tasks involving both arms, while DemoStart employs simulations to help the machine learn from its experiences. DeepMind envisions a future where AI robots will assist people with various tasks at home and in the workplace. The company believes that research into robot dexterity, including efficient and general learning approaches, is crucial to realizing this vision. This development underscores the ongoing efforts by tech companies to create robots capable of performing human-like activities, often seen as a critical measure of a robot's capabilities.

author: Alexandra Hartman
title: Record High Number of War Refugees
text:
War Displacement Crisis Reaches Shocking Decade-High Levels The number of people forcibly displaced due to war, violence, persecution, and human rights violations has reached alarming levels, marking a decade-high. This surge underscores a global crisis demanding urgent attention and coordinated action.
Key Factors Driving the Displacement Crisis Escalating conflicts across several regions are the primary drivers behind this surge in war displacement. violence, persecution, and human rights violations exacerbate the problem, forcing individuals and families to flee their homes in search of safety. This complex web of factors creates a dire situation for millions worldwide.
regional Hotspots and Their Impact Africa: Conflicts in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Sudan, and the Sahel region have led to massive internal and cross-border war displacement. Middle East: Ongoing turmoil in Syria, Yemen, and Palestine continues to displace populations, creating protracted refugee crises. Europe: The war in Ukraine has caused the fastest and largest war displacement crisis in Europe since World War II, with millions seeking refuge in neighboring countries. The Human Cost of War displacement War Displacement inflicts immense suffering on individuals and communities, resulting in trauma, loss, and separation. Vulnerable groups, including women, children, and minorities, are disproportionately affected. Access to basic necessities, such as food, shelter, and healthcare, becomes a daily struggle for those uprooted from their homes.
Did You Know? Children make up approximately 40% of the world‚Äôs refugee population, facing unique challenges including interrupted education and increased risk of exploitation.
Global Response and Humanitarian Aid International organizations, governments, and local communities are working to provide humanitarian assistance to those affected by war displacement.This includes providing shelter, food, medical care, and legal support. However, the scale of the crisis requires a notable increase in resources and coordinated efforts to meet the growing needs of displaced populations.
Pro Tip: Supporting local organizations can often be the most effective way to provide aid, as they are deeply embedded in the affected communities and understand the specific needs of the population.
The Long-Term Consequences The consequences of war displacement extend far beyond the immediate crisis. Displaced populations often face long-term challenges, including economic hardship, social disruption, and difficulties accessing education and employment. The trauma of war and displacement can have lasting psychological effects, requiring sustained mental health support.
Challenge Impact Potential Solution Economic Hardship Loss of livelihoods,increased poverty Job training programs,micro-loans Social Disruption Breakdown of social networks,increased vulnerability Community-based support groups,cultural preservation initiatives Education Barriers Interrupted schooling,limited opportunities Accelerated learning programs,scholarships Mental Health Issues Trauma,depression,anxiety Counseling services,psychosocial support What Can Be Done? Addressing the war displacement crisis requires a multi-faceted approach,including conflict resolution,humanitarian aid,and long-term development initiatives. Supporting peace-building efforts, promoting human rights, and investing in education and economic opportunities are crucial steps towards creating a more stable and inclusive world.
Understanding the War Displacement Crisis: An Evergreen Perspective The global refugee crisis is not a new phenomenon,but it is indeed evolving in complexity and scale. Understanding the historical context, the root causes, and the long-term impacts is essential for developing effective and sustainable solutions.
The complexities surrounding war displacement demand continuous monitoring and adaptation of strategies. As global dynamics shift, so too must our approaches to aiding and integrating displaced populations. What innovative solutions can be implemented to address the root causes of displacement?
Frequently Asked Questions About War Displacement What is the main cause of the increased war displacement? The primary drivers are escalating conflicts, violence, persecution, and human rights violations across various regions. Which populations are most affected by war displacement? Vulnerable groups, including women, children, and minorities, are disproportionately affected by forced war displacement. What support is available for those facing war displacement? International organizations and local communities provide humanitarian assistance, including shelter, food, medical care, and legal support to war displacement victims. How can individuals help those affected by war displacement? You can donate to reputable aid organizations, volunteer your time, raise awareness, and advocate for policies that protect refugees and displaced populations experiencing war displacement. What are the long-term consequences of war displacement? Long-term consequences include trauma, economic hardship, social disruption, and challenges in accessing education and employment for those affected by war displacement. What steps do you think world leaders should prioritize to address this growing crisis? Share your thoughts and help raise awareness about the urgent need for action.
Considering the current record high number of war refugees, what are the most effective long-term solutions to prevent future displacement crises, beyond immediate humanitarian aid?
Record High Number of War Refugees: A Global Humanitarian Crisis The world is facing an unprecedented crisis: a record high number of war refugees and forcibly displaced people. This humanitarian tragedy underscores the devastating impact of conflict, political instability, and persecution on communities globally. Understanding the scope and causes of this crisis is crucial for finding effective solutions and supporting those most vulnerable. The refugee crisis isn‚Äôt just a statistic; it involves real people, real stories, and real struggles. Understanding the global refugee crisis , and more specifically the number of refugees and their struggles is crucial.
driving Forces: Causes of the Refugee Crisis Several key factors contribute to the ever-growing number of war refugees and internally displaced persons. These factors often intertwine, exacerbating the displacement crisis and creating complex challenges for humanitarian organizations. One primary cause is armed conflict.Specifically, many of the current refugees are escaping the conflict in Ukraine, Syria, and Afghanistan.Other causes include:
Armed Conflict & War: protracted conflicts, such as those in Syria, Yemen, and the Democratic Republic of Congo, are significant drivers. Persecution & Human Rights Violations: Political instability and human rights abuses lead many to seek asylum. Examples include state repression and systemic discriminatory policies. Political Instability and Violence: Civil unrest and failures in governance create instability that forces people to flee their homes. Poverty and Economic Hardship: Extreme poverty and lack of economic opportunity, frequently exacerbated by conflict, can also force people to seek refuge. Climate Change Impacts: Climate change creates further conflicts and environmental disasters, which are displacing increasing numbers of people, known as ‚Äúclimate refugees‚Äù through climate-related displacement . The Impact of the Syrian Civil war the Syrian Civil War has been instrumental in creating severe refugee issues that continue to be felt worldwide. The scale and intensity of the conflict caused massive displacement both within Syria and into neighboring nations, with millions seeking refuge in Turkey, Lebanon, and Jordan, among other countries. The situation clearly highlights the consequences of protracted conflicts and their long-term effect on populations.
Refugees at the overcrowded camp. examining the Statistics: A Look at the Data
The sheer scale of the refugee crisis is alarming. Accurate statistics offer a clear picture of the scope of the global emergency. UNHCR , the United Nations refugee Agency, is a key resource for up-to-date information, providing regular reports on the number of refugees, asylum seekers, and internally displaced people (IDPs) worldwide. These numbers include detailed breakdowns by country of origin, host country, and the causes of displacement.
Below is a summary overview of some key figures providing more insight into the global displacement trend based on publicly available UNHCR data (Note: Data fluctuates and should be verified with latest reports from UNHCR):
Category Estimated Number notes Refugees Globally Over 117.2 million (as of 2023/2024) Includes those fleeing war, persecution, and violence. Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) Millions People displaced within their own country. Asylum Seekers Continously Fluctuating Individuals who are seeking asylum in a new country. People Under UNHCR Mandate vaste number Total number of individuals UNHCR helps, IDPs, stateless persons, etc. It‚Äôs important to note that these are minimum estimates ; challenges in data collection, particularly concerning IDPs, mean the actual numbers are likely higher.
efforts and Solutions: What‚Äôs Being Done Addressing the refugee crisis requires a multifaceted approach, including humanitarian aid, political solutions, and long-term development initiatives. Several international organizations are at the forefront of this undertaking:
UNHCR: The UN Refugee Agency provides protection and assistance to refugees globally, including shelter, food, and medical aid. World Food Program (WFP): Delivers food assistance to refugees and displaced populations worldwide. International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement: Offers humanitarian assistance, including medical care and disaster relief in crisis zones. National Governments and NGOs: Many countries are providing direct support, including resettlement programs ,and the refugee integration, through the government or partnering with NGOs. The role of International Law and Response International law, particularly the 1951 Refugee Convention, establishes a framework for protecting refugees and defining their rights. Countries are responsible for providing asylum to those meeting the definition of a refugee. Enforcement of these conventions at a global scale plays a vital role and is critical. Supporting international cooperation and diplomatic efforts to resolve conflicts in their origins is also vital to reduce the number of displaced persons .
how You can definitely help There are numerous ways to contribute to the cause and help war refugees, whether through monetary donations, volunteering your time, or raising awareness within your communities.
Donate to reputable organizations: Directly support UNHCR, Red Cross, Doctors Without Borders, or smaller, local NGOs. Advocate for policies: Contact your elected officials and advocate for policies that increase aid. Raise awareness: Use social media; talk with family, friends about the crisis; and promote accurate information. Volunteer your time: Look for opportunities at local resettlement agencies or schools working with refugee communities. Sponsor a refugee family: Many organizations facilitate sponsorship programs. Support resettlement efforts: support initiatives focused.
